Meet Qubo


View 3D Model

Understanding Qubo

As Tortuga's hardware aged and its software became outdated, we decided to create a completely new vehicle. Qubo, the Swahili word for turtle, is designed to be modular, upgradeable, and flexible. The platform incorporates the latest hardware, and viable and robust for years to come.

Batteries

In Qubo, two external hot-swappable batteries will supply power to our systems. Each will be housed in it own pressure hull with its own monitoring circuit and switch. When one battery drains, another can be safely plugged in without loss of power. This avoids provious problems caused by batteries being housed in the main electronics hull. The prior setup required us to open the hull in order to remove batteries, leading to O-ring damage and long charging times.

Camera

We use two Mako IP camera for vision: one pointing forward and one pointing downward. They gather visual data about the environment ahead of the robot as well as below it. We are currently experimenting with a smaller camera hull to replace the existing one. Qubo's modular design allows us to make these changes without greatly impacting the other systems.

Electronic Hull

The electronics hull houses all of Qubo's electronics, including the main computer, an Nvidia Jetson TX1. On one side, the CPU endcap dissipates heat generated by the Jetson while allowing underwater electrical connectors to be mounted. On the other side, the connector endcap is a heatsink for thruster speed controllers (ESC) and their corresponding penetrators. A rail system in the middle carries the backplane and the daughterboards. In the future, we wish to redesign the hull interior mounting system to accommodate a zero-insertion-force-connector.

Instruments

Qubo's instruments track its movements and position. The Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) tracks acceleration, orientation, and magnetic direction. The Doppler Velocity Log (DVL) measures the exact velocity of vehicle, allowing it to calculate its positions. The depth sensor detects the depth of vehicle.

Thrusters

We use 8 Blue Robotics T200 thruster, mounted on the corners of Qubo, to give us a full range of motion. This covers all six degrees of freedom while providing redundancy in case a thruster malfunctions.

Pneumatic System

A pneumatic system (a system that is powered by high-pressure gas) allows us to perform underwater tasks without the help of specially insulated electric motors. We use 12 gram canisters of compressed carbon dioxide as Qubo's source of power. A series of manifolds (chambers) distributes the high-pressure air to pneumatic cylinders that drive various mechanisms.

Frame

The frame holds all of the components in their correct positions. Usually this is designed last after a team has finalized the positions of their various systems. However, Qubo's modular platform allows us to add and move systems as needed. The cub-shaped frame has dozens of mounting points machined into it. In addition, the side panels water-jetted out of aluminum sheets and held together with 8 corner brackets, 4 main structs, and 2 reinforcement bars.

Future Plans for Qubo

1. Mechanical Projects

  • Explore underwater servo/stepper to create a 6-DOF robotics arm
  • Develop robotic arm control algorithm
  • Design and manufacture an integrated torpedo launcher and marker dropper
  • Design a new pressure hull to house front and downward facing cameras
  • Design an effective gripper for tubular objects

2. Sonar Sensing

  • Develop a passive sonar array to detect and navigate to a sonar pinger
  • Develop signal processing boards to process inputs from hydorphones
